questions.text:
1. Match the following patients with their respective speech audiometric graphs.

* A patient with episodic vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss and tinnitus.

* A patient with hearing loss and tinnitus and MRI showing "ice-cream-cone" appearance.

* A patient with right-sided hearing loss and Weber's test lateralized to right ear.

* A patient with normal hearing.
questions.solution:
The correct match is as follows:

* A patient with episodic vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss and tinnitus (Meniere's disease) - Graph C

* A patient with hearing loss and tinnitus and MRI showing "ice-cream-cone" appearance (Acoustic neuroma)- Graph D

* A patient with right-sided hearing loss and Weber's test lateralized to right ear (Conductive deafness) - Graph B

* A patient with normal hearing - Graph A

In speech audiometry, the patient’s ability to hear and understand speech is measured. Speech reception threshold (SRT) and discrimination score (DS) are studied under this test.

The speech reception threshold (SRT) is the lowest intensity of sound at which 50% of the words are repeated correctly by the patient. Speech discrimination scores test the capacity of the patient to understand speech. Hence, speech audiometry is a subjective test which is difficult to perform in children of younger age.

Roll over phenomenon (Graph D) which is seen on plotting discrimination score against amplitude of sound is diagnostic of Retrochochlear pathologies that is indicative of neural hearing loss. Here, the phoneticaly balanced (PB) word score falls with increase in speech intensity above a particular level due to nerve fatigue.

The graph in cochlear disorders (Graph C) will rather show a plateau after a certain level unlike the fall seen in roll over phenomenon.



Pearl PM1753: Speech audiometry

Consists of two components:

* Speech reception threshold: The minimum intensity at which 50% of the words are repeated correctly by the patient.

* Speech discrimination score: The patient’s ability to understand speech.

* Percentage of phonetically balanced words delivered 30dB above SRT which are identified correctly.

* In normal persons and those with conductive hearing loss, a high score of 90–100% can be obtained.

* It is reduced in cochlear lesions, very poor and out of proportion to hearing loss in retrocochlear hearing loss, and worst in cortical deafness.

Roll-over phenomenon:

* Feature of retrocochlear hearing loss.

* When speech intensity is increased above a particular level, SDS falls instead of maintaining a plateau as in cochlear deafness.

Uses:

* To differentiate organic from non-organic hearing loss.

* To differentiate cochlear from retrocochlear lesions.

* To find the intensity at which discrimination score is the best which is useful for fitting a hearing aid.



Pearl PM1752: The differences between cochlear and retrocochlear hearing loss

Test
Cochlear hearing loss
Retrocochlear hearing loss
Recruitment (ABLB test)
Present
Absent
*SISI score (Short Increment Sensitivity Index)
70 – 100%
0 – 20% 
Acoustic reflex threshold
Decreased due to recruitment
Increased
**Tone decay (nerve fatigue)
Absent
Present
Acoustic reflex decay (nerve fatigue)
Absent
Present
OAEs
Absent
Present
BERA (Best test)
Delayed wave-I, rest are normal
Only wave-I is present, rest are absent or affected
Speech discrimination score
  • Reduced
  • Roll over phenomenon absent
  • Very poor
  • Roll over phenomenon present


*Short Increment Sensitivity Index: A normal ear can’t differentiate short increments of sound but a recruiting ear can. SISI test is started sound 20db above the hearing threshold of the patient and 20 increments of 1db are given every 5 seconds. The total number of increments heard by the patient is recorded. SISI score of 70-100% is seen in cochlear deafness and of 0-20% in retrocochlear deafness.

** Threshold tone decay: It is a function of nerve fatigue. A Tone of 4000Hz is presented at 5dB above the patient’s threshold of hearing for 60 seconds. A normal ear can hear continuously for a minute but a patient with abnormal hearing stops hearing before 1 minute. Loudness is increased until the patient can hear the sound. If loudness has to be increased by more than 30dB, it indicates retrocochlear hearing loss.

questions.text: 2. A 12-year-old boy with a history of laryngeal papillomatosis for which he underwent multiple laryngoscopies and surgeries eventually developed iatrogenic tracheal stenosis. Which of the following flow-volume loops is expected to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario the patient has developed tracheal stenosis secondary to multiple laryngoscopies and surgeries. Thus the flow-volume curve expected to be seen in this patient is depicted in figure C.

Tracheal stenosis is an example of fixed obstruction due to airway narrowing. Fixed lesions cause plateaus in both the inspiratory and expiratory limbs of the flow volume loop thereby producing the characteristic flattened loop. 

Examples of fixed lesions include subglottic stenosis, tracheal tumors, and thyroid pathologies such as goiters. 

The flow-volume loop is a graphical representation of inspiratory and expiratory flow (shown on the Y-axis) against volume (shown on the X-axis) plotted while performing maximally forced inspiratory and expiratory maneuvers.



Pearl PM1835: Flow-volume graph/Loop

questions.text:
3. The image given below shows the normal JVP waveform. Which of the following wave component is responsible for atrial filling during ventricular systole?

JVP - Jugular venous pressure
questions.solution:
The v-wave of the JVP waveform is responsible for the atrial filling during ventricular systole.

JVP measured in the internal jugular vein (IJV) is a reflection of the right atrial pressure. IJV is preferred because it is not valved and is in direct line with the superior vena cava and right atrium.

The illustration given below shows a normal JVP waveform.



The waveforms seen in a normal JVP are:

* a wave corresponds to atrial contraction (systole) and occurs just after the P wave (on ECG) and just before the first heart sound.

* c wave represents the bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during ventricular systole.

* x descent corresponds to the atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

* v wave represents atrial filling during ventricular systole and peaks at the second heart sound.

* y descent represents passive emptying of the right atrium into the right ventricle after tricuspid valve opening, during which both the right atrium and right ventricle are in diastole. 

 The illustration given below shows a Wiggers diagram that correlates JVP with other aspects of the cardiac cycle.



Pearl PM2416: JVP waveform and the abnormalities



1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions
Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis
Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation


 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions
Absent x-descent Severe tricuspid regurgitation
Rapid x-descent Cardiac tamponade


 

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions
Dominant v-waves Tricuspid regurgitation


 

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

Abnormality Conditions
Prolonged y-descent Tricuspid stenosis
Rapid y-descent

Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation
Absent y-descent Cardiac tamponade

questions.text: 4. If voltage-gated potassium channels are blocked in the below marked phase of the myocyte action potential, which of the following is the most likely result?

choices.text: Membrane potential will become more positive
Membrane potential will become more negative
Membrane potential will reach resting value

questions.solution:
The marked phase of the myocyte action potential is phase 2 or the plateau phase. Blocking the voltage-gated K+ channels during this phase would lead to the membrane potential becoming more positive. 

During the plateau phase of the myocyte action potential, the Ca2+ influx from the L-type Ca2+ channels balances out the K+ efflux through the voltage-gated K+ channel, and thus the membrane potential remains in a plateau. However, if the voltage-gated K+ channels are blocked during this phase, it would lead to the unopposed entry of Ca2+ into the cell, which will make the membrane potential more positive.



The phases in the myocyte action potential are as follows:

Phase 0: Depolarization occurs due to the opening of voltage-gated Na+ channels (fast sodium channels) and Na+ influx.

Phase 1: Initial repolarization occurs due to the closure of the inactivation gate of the Na+ channels and the opening up of K+ channels, leading to a net outward current. 

Phase 2: Plateau consists of relatively stable, depolarized membrane potential. During this phase, Ca2+ ions move into the cell because of the opening of L-type Ca2+ channels. This is balanced by the K+ ions moving out due to open K+ channels. This causes the membrane potential to remain at a stable depolarized value. The Ca2+ entry during the plateau phase potentiates the release of more Ca2+ from the intracellular stores for myocyte contraction. This is known as calcium-induced calcium release. 

Phase 3: Rapid repolarization occurs due to the closure of Ca2+ channels and K+ ions still moving out of the cell due to open K+ channels, leading to a net outward current. At the end of phase 3, the K+ current decreases because the membrane potential approaches the equilibrium potential of K+.

Phase 4: Resting membrane potential.

questions.text: 5. Which of the following is true with respect to phase B of bacterial growth curve?

choices.text: Rapid increase in size of bacterial cell is seen
Viable and non-culturable organisms can be seen
Steeper phase B can be possible with lesser generation time
Steeper phase B is seen with fastidious organisms

questions.solution:
In phase B (log phase) bacteria divide by multiplication. The time it takes to multiply is called generation time. With a lesser time taken to multiply, the division is faster, and therefore, phase B would be steeper.

Phases of bacterial growth: 

* Lag phase (Marked as A): Occurs immediately after the seeding of a culture media. There is no increase in cell number but cell size increases and maximum cell size is obtained towards the end of this phase. This initial period is the time required for adaptation to a new environment, during which the necessary enzymes and metabolic intermediates are built up in adequate quantities for multiplication to proceed.

* Log phase or exponential phase (Marked as B): In this phase, cells start dividing and their numbers increase exponentially or by geometric progression with time. Cells are smaller and stain uniformly. 

* Stationary phase (Marked as C): Cell division stops due to depletion of nutrients and accumulation of toxic products. Its a state of equilibrium, where the number of new cells forms equals the number of cells that die. Sporulation occurs during this phase. Many bacteria produce secondary metabolic products such as exotoxins and antibiotics.

* Phase of decline (Marked as D): In this phase, the population decreases due to cell death from nutritional exhaustion, toxin accumulation, and the action of autolytic enzymes. Involution forms are common.

Other options:

A rapid increase in bacterial cell size is a feature of the Lag phase (Phase A).

Viable and non-culturable cells are seen in stationary phase (Phase C).

Fastidious organisms are difficult to grow because of their specific growth requirements, they are less likely to grow fast.

questions.text:
6. A 58-year-old man presented with a history of lymph node enlargement in his neck and axillae for the past 3 weeks. Investigations revealed mild anemia, with a leukocytosis of 40,000/mm3. The flow cytometry of cells is as given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

DLBCL: Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma

CLL: Chronic lymphocytic leukemia
questions.solution:
The given pattern is suggestive of B-CLL.

Interpreting flow cytometry graph:

See the markers on X-axis and Y-axis. Divide the graph into 4 quadrants.

1) In the first graph, X-axis shows CD5 and Y-axis shows CD19. The particular cell population in question is positive for CD19 and CD5.

2) In the second graph, it is shown the cells are negative for CD10 and positive for CD19.

3) The third graph shows CD 23 is positive. CD20 is dimly expressed.

4) FMC-7 is negative. CD20 is dimly expressed.

It is understood from the cytometry analysis that the cells are positive for CD5, CD19, CD23, CD20.  All these suggest the diagnosis of B-CLL.

Other options:

* Mantle cell lymphoma can be diagnosed by its characteristic immunophenotype: CD19+, CD20+, CD21+, CD22+, CD23(-), CD 5+.

* DLBCL and Follicular lymphoma are positive for CD10.

Comparison between Mantle Cell Lymphoma and Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia/Small Lymphocytic Lymphoma (CLL/SLL):

  Mantle cell lymphoma CLL/SLL
CD5 Positive Positive
CD23 Negative Positive
Cyclin D1 Positive Negative
FMC7 Positive Negative
CD10, BCL6 Negative Negative


Pearl PM0671: Origin of leukemia / lymphoma and their immunophenotypes

B cell precursors Derived lymphomas/leukemia Immunophenotype
Pro-B cell Pro-B cell ALL CD34, CD19, CD79a
Pre-B cell Pre-B cell ALL CD19, CD79a, CD10, Tdt
Mature B cell CLL/SLL

CD19, CD79a,CD 20, CD21, CD22, surface IgM, CD 23, CD5
Mantle zone Mantle zone lymphoma CD19, CD79a,CD 20, CD21, CD22, surface IgM, CD5
Germinal center/Follicular center

Follicular lymphoma

 

Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma

Burkitt lymphoma

CD 79a, CD 19, CD20, CD21,CD22, CD10, CD 23, Bcl-2

CD10, Cd23, Bcl-6

CD19, CD20, CD22, CD79a, CD10, Bcl-6
Memory B cells Extranodal marginal zone lymphoma CD19, CD79a,CD 20, surface Ig


CLL: Chronic lymphocytic leukemia 

SLL: Small lymphocytic lymphoma

questions.text: 7. A patient’s ABG was consistent with the curve X in the nomogram given below with serum Na: 138 mEq/L, serum Cl: 110 mEq/L and serum HCO3-: 19 mEq/L. Which of the following can be a differential diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario shows a normal gap (hyperchloremic) metabolic acidosis, characteristic of RTA (renal tubular acidosis).

The anion gap in this patient can be calculated as Na+ – (Cl- + HCO3-) = 138– (110+19) = 138 - 129 = 9.

The normal anion gap ranges from 6 to 12 mmol/L, with an average of 10 mmol/L. Among the given options, only renal tubular acidosis is associated with normal anion gap metabolic acidosis.

All of the other options cause high anion gap metabolic acidosis.

Causes of high anion gap metabolic acidosis:

* Methanol

* Uremia (chronic kidney failure)

* Diabetic ketoacidosis

* Paracetamol, Propylene glycol

* Infection, Iron, Isoniazid

* Lactic acidosis

* Ethylene glycol

* Salicylates



Pearl PM1521: Causes of Metabolic Acidosis

High Anion-Gap Metabolic Acidosis (MUDPILES) Normal Anion-Gap Metabolic Acidosis (FUSED CAR)
Methanol Fistula pancreatic
Uremia (Renal failure - Acute or Chronic) Ureterosigmoidostomy
Diabetic ketoacidosis Small bowel fistula
Paraldehyde Extra chloride (Hyperalimentation)
Iron tablets, INH Diarrhea
Lactic acidosis Carbonic anhydrase inhibitor (acetazolamide)
Ethylene glycol Addison's disease
Salicylates Renal tubular acidosis


Pearl PM2110: Characteristics of renal tubular acidosis (RTA)

Pearl PM2409: Acid-Base Balance - Normal Values

questions.text: 8. On noticing the capnography of a patient showing the tracing below, which of the following would you suspect?
questions.solution:
The above capnographic waveform shows an elevated inspiratory baseline, which depicts rebreathing. Rebreathing of CO2 may occur due to exhausted CO2 absorbent or incompetent expiratory valve in closed-circuit breathing systems.



Waveform capnography is a continuous non-invasive measurement and graphical display of the EtCO2. It is a direct measure of lung ventilation and an indirect measure of circulation and metabolism.

The normal capnograph displays the exhaled CO2 in both the inspiratory and expiratory phases. The expiratory phase is divided into three distinct components:

* Phase I: Exhaled dead space gas 

* Phase II: A sharp rise in pCO2 to a plateau, indicating the transitional gas between the airways and alveoli. 

* Phase III: The plateau that corresponds to the pCO2 in the alveoli. 

* Following phase III, there is a sharp inspiratory downstroke. It is referred to as the beginning of phase 0 or phase IV by some authors.



Other options:

Option A: Esophageal intubation shows a capnograph with some carbon dioxide detected initially followed by the absence of carbon dioxide. Swallowed air in the stomach would cause the initial detection of CO2 which is soon washed out and the ETCO2 comes to zero.



Option B: In the capnograph of a patient with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, there is no plateau before the next inspiration with an increased up-slope of phase III. Seen in bronchospasm (asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease), or if the endotracheal tube or breathing circuit is partially obstructed.



Option D: A dramatic increase in body temperature and muscle rigidity suggests malignant hyperthermia. The increased metabolic rate caused by malignant hyperthermia causes a marked rise in ETCO2.



Pearl PM0186: Various capnography waveforms:



A- Obstructive airway or bronchospasm B- Expiratory valve malfunctioning C- Inspiratory valve malfunction D- Normal physiological variant seen in pregnant subjects under GA E- Curare cleft F- Rebreathing G- Esophageal intubation H- Spontaneous breathing I-Dual capnogram in one lung transplantation patient. The first peak in phase III is from the transplanted normal lung, whereas the second peak is from the native disease lung. A variation of dual capnogram (steeple sign capnogram – dotted line) is seen if there is a leak around the sidestream sensor port at the monitor J- Malignant hyperthermia K- Classic ripple effect during the expiratory pause showing cardiogenic oscillations L- Sudden rise of baseline and end-tidal PCO2 (PETCO2) due to contamination of the sensor with secretions or water vapor. The gradual rise of baseline and PETCO2 occurs when soda lime is exhausted.  M -Intermittent mechanical ventilation (IMV) breaths in the midst of spontaneously breathing patient. N -Cardiopulmonary resuscitation: capnogram showing positive waveforms during each compression.  O-Capnogram showing rebreathing during inspiration. This is normal in rebreathing circuits such as Mapleson D or Bain circuit.

Pearl PM2229: Signs of correct endotracheal intubation

* Detection of end-tidal CO2 by capnography (Surest confirmation)

* Symmetric chest rise

* Bilateral breath sounds

* Absence of breath sounds in the epigastrium

* Visible condensation in the endotracheal tube

* Large exhaled tidal volumes

* Appropriate compliance of the reservoir bag during manual ventilation

questions.text: 9. An oxygen hemoglobin dissociation curve of a 30-year-old athlete was recorded. If curve 3 represents the dissociation curve during rest, how would the graph shift if he was exercising?
questions.solution:
From the given scenario, during exercise, the oxygen hemoglobin curve shifts considerably towards the right and is denoted by the curve 4.

Curve 3 represents the normal oxygen hemoglobin curve during rest. 

Conditions that cause a right shift (curve 3 to curve 4) in the oxygen hemoglobin curve are: (Conditions with the increased requirement of O2 - metabolically active tissues)

* Hypoxia and Hypercarbia - Metabolically active tissues utilize O2 and tissues produce CO2

* ↓ pH - Secondary to increased CO2 production

* ↑ in temperature, heat

* ↑ in 2,3-DPG - increased anaerobic glycolysis

Conditions that cause a left shift (curve 3 to curve 2)  in the oxygen hemoglobin dissociation curve are:

* Decreased carbon dioxide

* ↑ pH of the blood

* ↓ in the temperature of the body

Curve 1 represents the Myoglobin-O2 binding curve. It is a rectangular hyperbola (unlike a sigmoid curve of the oxygen-hemoglobin curve). This is because it only has a single oxygen binding site. It is present in muscles in large amounts and can provide oxygen to muscles even at low blood oxygen levels.



Pearl PM0996: Factors affecting 2,3 -DPG

↑ in 2, 3-DPG ↓ in 2, 3-DPG
  • Anemia
  • Acclimitization (high altitude)
  • Thyroid hormone
  • Growth hormone
  • Androgens
  • Exercise
  • Chronic hypoxia
  • Stored blood
  • Acidosis

questions.text:
10. A patient presents with episodes of vertigo, hearing loss in the left ear, and a ringing sensation in the ear. PTA findings are shown in the image below. Which of the following structures produces the ear fluid accumulated in this condition?

PTA - Pure tone audiometry
questions.solution:
The given clinical history of episodic vertigo,  hearing loss, and tinnitus. Then, the Pure tone audiometry (PTA) revealing sensorineural hearing loss and showing 'rising' curve is suggestive of Meniere's disease. Endolymph is responsible for the pathophysiology and it is produced by stria vascularis.

Endolymph is the fluid that fills the membranous labyrinth in the ear. It is rich in potassium ions and secreted by special cells in the stria vascularis of the cochlea and the dark cells in the utricle and near the ampullated ends of semicircular ducts. There are two theories about its flow: longitudinal and radial. The longitudinal flow passes through the endolymphatic duct and is absorbed by the endolymphatic sac, while the stria vascularis absorb the radial flow. 

Meniere's disease occurs due to increased production or decreased drainage of endolymph leading to increased volume and distension of the endolymphatic system. Clinical features include episodic vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, tinnitus, and fullness of the ear. 

Rinne's test is positive and Weber's test shows lateralization to the better ear, suggestive of sensorineural hearing loss. Pure tone audiometry (PTA) will reveal sensorineural hearing loss. Initially, the lower frequencies are affected resulting in a 'rising' curve. Later in disease progression, higher frequencies are affected leading to a 'flat' or 'falling' curve.

Pearl PM0537: Inner ear fluids

  Perilymph Endolymph
Found in Bony labyrinth Membranous labyrinth
Similar to Extracellular fluid Intracellular fluid
Rich in Na+ ions K+ ions
Formation Filtrate of blood/ directly from CSF Produced by stria vascularis
Drainage Into CSF via cochlear aqueduct Absorbed through endolymphatic sac

questions.text: 11. “a” wave in ERG corresponds to the activity of
questions.solution:
"a" wave in ERG corresponds to activity of rods and cones.

The electroretinogram (ERG) is a diagnostic test that measures the electrical activity generated by neural and non-neuronal cells in the retina in response to a light stimulus.

The normal ERG is predominantly biphasic:

* a-wave: Initial corneal-negative deflection, derived from the cones and rods of the outer photoreceptor layers

* b-wave: Corneal-positive deflection; derived from the inner retina, predominantly Muller and bipolar cells

* c-wave: Derived from the retinal pigment epithelium and photoreceptors

questions.text:
12. Match the following scattergrams with their correlation coefficient.

A) 0 B) -0.5 C) +1 D) +0.5
questions.solution:
Correlation (denoted by r) is used to assess the strength and direction of the association between two variables (such as smoking and lung cancer).

The correlation coefficient is represented by a plus or minus sign, followed by a number (Example: -0.88). The correlation coefficient ranges from -1 to +1.

The numerical indicates the strength of correlation:

* +1 or -1 suggests the maximum possible strength of the correlation.

* Values closer to 1 have greater strength of the correlation.

* Correlation coefficients greater than +/- 0.5 are suggested as strong and are likely to establish (if positive correlation) or disprove (if negative correlation) the association between two factors.

The sign indicates the direction of correlation.

* Plus sign (+) suggests that both the variables being studied are positively correlated, which implies that the variables are associated (Ex: Smoking and lung cancer have a positive correlation ).

* Minus sign (-) suggests that both the variables being studied are negatively correlated, which implies that the variables are inversely associated with each other (Ex: Alcohol intake and Malaria have a negative correlation).

* For example, both -0.88 and +0.88, represent the same strength of the correlation. However, +0.88 suggests a positive correlation, and -0.88 suggests a negative correlation.

Pearl PM1139: Correlation

Correlation expresses the strength and direction of the relationship between two variables in terms of a correlation coefficient. It is represented by r.

* Values of r vary from -1 (perfect negative correlation) to +1 (perfect positive correlation).

* Value (size) of the coefficient: Indicates the strength of relationship

* Sign of the coefficient: Indicates direction of relationship

Coefficients between ±0.5 and 1 are regarded as strong whereas those between ±0.5 and 0 are regarded as weak.

The data is plotted in a scattergram as shown in the examples given below

Examples:



Types of correlation coefficients

* Pearson coefficient

* Spearman coefficient



Coefficient of Determination (CD) =  r2

It is simply the percentage variability in one factor due to change in another variable.

questions.text: 13. The dose-response curves of isoprenaline for cardiac stimulation and bronchodilation are separated from each other owing to which of the following?
questions.solution:
The significant separation between the two curves on the dose-response curve (DRC) indicates that the dosage needed to elicit one effect is considerably greater than the other. This occurs because of selectivity at different doses.

The graph shown below depicts that at lower doses, the selective response is bronchodilation. While at higher doses the selective response is cardiac stimulation.



Dose response curve depicts potency, efficacy of a drug which is used to compare different drugs on the basis of their efficacy and potency. For example : Pethidine is less potent but equally efficacious as morphine and furosemide is less potent but more efficacious diuretic than metolazone.

A drug can produce more than one action, the DRCs for different effects of a drug may be different. The extent of separation of DRCs of a drug for different effects is a measure of its selectivity at different doses. For example : Isoprenaline has similar DRCs for bronchodilation and cardiac stimulation, making it less selective. In contrast, salbutamol has widely separated DRCs for these effects, making it a more selective bronchodilator.

questions.text: 14. A 70-year-old diabetic female complains of frequent urination, but no pain or burning micturition. She has an urgency to pass the urine but passes urine before reaching the lavatory. Which phase of the cystometrogram is likely to be altered in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario given above is suggestive of urge incontinence or overactive bladder and Phase Ib, marked as 2 in the image, is shortened in this condition.

An overactive bladder is characterised by an uncontrolled contraction of the detrusor muscle in the bladder wall, causing an uncontrollable urge to urinate. This can happen anytime throughout phase 1b (2 in the diagram) of the cystometrogram, resulting in a shorter phase. 

A cystometrogram is a plot of intravesical pressure against the volume of fluid in the bladder. The curve shows three segments:

* Ia- initial slight rise in pressure when the first increments in the volume are produced

* Ib- long, nearly flat segment as further increments are produced

* II- a sudden, sharp rise in pressure as the micturition reflex is triggered (not failure).

* The dotted line- pressure-volume relation if the micturition had not occurred.

The flatness of segment Ib is a demonstration of the law of Laplace. The law of Laplace states that the pressure (P) in a spherical viscus is equal to twice the wall tension (T) divided by the radius (R). This is expressed as P= 2T/R. In the blad­der, the tension increases as the bladder gets filled. Since the radius also increases, there is only a slight increase in pressure until the bladder is relatively full.

questions.text: 15. Which of the following serological titers in a patient with acute hepatitis B has been incorrectly labeled?
questions.solution:
In the given graph of serological markers, in a patient with acute hepatitis B infection curve 4 is incorrectly labeled. Curve 4 represents, IgM Anti HBc.

The parameters marked in the graph respectively include:

* HBsAg antigen

* Anti HBs

* Total Anti HBc

* IgM Anti HBc

Hepatitis B virus contains a 27-nm nucleocapsid core particle which is coded for by the C gene. The antigen expressed on the surface of the nucleocapsid core is hepatitis B core antigen (HBcAg), and its corresponding antibody is anti-HBc. Because HBcAg is intracellular and sequestered within an HBsAg coat, naked core particles do not circulate in serum, and therefore, HBcAg is not detectable routinely in the serum of patients with HBV infection.

Specific diagnosis of hepatitis B rests on the serological demonstration of the viral markers:

* HBsAg is the first marker seen in the blood following infection and can be detected prior to the clinical manifestation and elevation of transaminases. Typically, they disappear within about two months of the start of clinical disease, but may sometimes persist for six months.

* Anti-HBs antibodies are protective antibodies and they appear when the antigens are no longer detectable and they remain for very long periods. 

* Anti-HBc antibody is the earliest marker seen in blood a week or two after the appearance of HBsAg. IgM anti-HBc is predominant in acute infections. Later, it is replaced by IgG anti-HBc. It remains for a lifetime and thus indicates a prior infection.

* HBeAg appears in blood along with HBsAg or following its appearance. Circulating HBeAg is an indicator of active intrahepatic viral replication, and the presence of DNA polymerase, HBV DNA, and virions, reflect high infectivity.

Note:

* Recovery from hepatitis B: Anti-HBsAg and Anti-HBc IgG will be positive in case of recovery.

* History of Hepatitis B in the remote past: Anti-HBc IgG is the serological marker.

* Chronic hepatitis with low infectivity: HBsAg, Anti-HBeAg, and Anti-HBc IgG will be positive.

* In immunized individuals, only Anti-HBsAg will be positive.

Pearl PM1680: Interpretation of common serologic patterns in hepatitis B infection



 

 Clinical Phases HBsAg Anti-HBs HBeAg Anti-HBe Anti-HBc HBV DNA

Acute HBV - Early-phase,
high infectivity

 + - + - IgM +++
Acute HBV -Window phase - - +/- +/- IgM +
Acute HBV - recovery phase - + - +/- IgG +/-
Chronic HBV, high infectivity + - + - IgG +++
Chronic HBV, low infectivity + - - + IgG +
HBV infection in the recent past - + - - IgM -
HBV infection in the remote past - - - +/- IgG -
Post-vaccination - + - - - -

questions.text:
16. A patient with complaints of excessive thirst and increased frequency of urination is evaluated with a water deprivation test. The findings are as shown in the graph below. What does this indicate?

ADH: Antidiuretic hormone
questions.solution:
The given graph represents the urine and serum osmolality after conducting the water deprivation test and suggests central diabetes insipidus.  

This graph indicates that on withholding water there is no response but on administration of vasopressin, there is an increase in the serum and urine osmolality. This shows that the kidneys respond to antidiuretic hormone, hence this curve indicates central diabetes insipidus.

Diabetes insipidus can be of two types - central or peripheral (nephrogenic). Central DI occurs due to a deficiency of ADH. 

Central diabetes insipidus (DI) is a disorder of the posterior pituitary. It is characterized by decreased ADH leading to large volumes of urine production. Patients present with excessive thirst, nocturia, and urinary frequency. The urine is dilute with an osmolarity of < 300 mOsm/L. The 24-hour urine volume is >40 ml/kg and the basal plasma ADH is <1 pg/ml.

Central DI occurs due to damage to the neurohypophysis in the posterior pituitary. It can be congenital or acquired.

Central DI can be treated with desmopressin, an ADH analogue. Nephrogenic DI requires treatment with a thiazide diuretic, amiloride, low sodium diet, and indomethacin. 

Primary polydipsia can be caused either by compulsory water drinking(dipsogenic polydipsia) or psychogenic polydipsia. Here while the body is still physiologically normal, the responses to water deprivation and vasopressin isn't as robust as a normal individual. 

Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus has no response to water-deprivation test.



Pearl PM1536: Water Deprivation test in Diabetes Insipidus

Procedure: Start the test at 4 am by checking the baseline urine osmolality. Deprive the patient of water till 12 pm (8 hours), and then re-check urine osmolality. 



  Urine osmolality before water deprivation Urine osmolality after water deprivation Urine osmolality after desmopressin administration
Normal  Normal  Increases No change
Central DI Low No change >50% increase from baseline
Nephrogenic DI Low No change <10% increase from baseline
Primary polydipsia Low Increases No change


Note: Normal urine osmolality- 500-850 mOsm/L

Pearl PM1534: Causes of Central Diabetes insipidus

* Neoplasms: 

* Pituitary adenomas (most common)

* Meningioma

* Metastasis from lung and breast cancers

* Infiltrative: 

* Sarcoidosis

* Langerhans cell histiocytosis

* Genetic: 

* Wolfram syndrome

* Hand-Schuller-Christian disease 

* Infections: 

* Chronic meningitis

* Viral encephalitis

* Toxoplasmosis

*  Inflammatory:

* Granulomatosis with polyangiitis

* Lupus erythematosus

* Scleroderma

*  Vascular:

* Sheehan’s syndrome

* Aneurysm (internal carotid)

* Head injury (closed and penetrating) including pituitary surgery

* Snakebite

* Lymphocytic hypophysitis

*

questions.text:
17. Given below is a graph charting the hormone levels in a normal pregnancy. Which of the following hormones is represented by curve 1?

(hCG - human chorionic gonadotropin)

(hCS - human chorionic somatomammotropin)
questions.solution:
In the given graph of hormone levels in a normal pregnancy, the hormone represented by curve 1 is human chorionic gonadotropin. 

Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) is a hormone secreted in pregnancy. It is a glycoprotein similar in structure to LH, FSH and TSH. It is produced by the syncytiotrophoblast of the placenta. hCG maintains the corpus luteum for secretion of estrogen and progesterone till 13 to 17 weeks after conception and thus has a role to play in maintaining early pregnancy. 

hCG can be detected in the blood by radio-immunoassay as soon as 8 to 9 days after ovulation. It peaks at 10 to 12 weeks of gestation and then falls by the 16th to 20th week. It remains at this low level for the rest of the pregnancy. 

hCG can also be detected as early as 14 days after conception in urine, which is more commonly used as a sample for pregnancy diagnosis. However, hCG is not specific for the diagnosis of pregnancy, as hCG is also detected in gastrointestinal tumors in both males and females.



Curve 2 represents estrogen (option C), and curve 3 represents progesterone (option D). In pregnancy, both hormones are secreted in large quantities by the placenta. Estrogen levels rise steadily throughout pregnancy. However, from the seventh month onwards, progesterone secretion remains constant. Thus, the estrogen-to-progesterone ratio increases towards the end of pregnancy, as depicted by curve 2 crossing curve 3 towards the latter half of pregnancy.  

Human chorionic somatomammotropin (hCS) (option B) is a protein hormone secreted from the placenta during the 5th week of pregnancy. Its levels rise throughout pregnancy. hCS causes decreased insulin sensitivity in the pregnant woman and acts similarly to growth hormone.

questions.text: 18. A term baby’s weight was plotted as shown below. Which of the following complications may not be expected in this baby?
questions.solution:
The graph plots the birth weight of a baby below the 10 percentile which helps define a small for gestational age baby and hypercalcemia is not a complication.

Complications of infants born small for gestational age include intrauterine fetal demise due to hypoxia, infection, acidosis or any lethal anomaly. Other potential complications include perinatal asphyxia, hypoglycemia, hypothermia, hypocalcemia, polycythemia, meconium aspiration syndrome, persistent pulmonary hypertension, and pulmonary haemorrhage.

Small for gestational age (SGA) implies birthweight is <10th percentile for gestational age. They are constitutionally small and nearly 70% of the babies falling under this category are not at any increased risk for adverse outcomes and will eventually attain normal growth patterns. The rest of the 30% are growth-restricted and at increased risk of morbidity and mortality. Thus, SGA is not universally associated with growth restriction.

Concerning birth weight percentile, a newborn can be appropriate, small or large for gestational age.

Birth weight Terminology
<10th percentile Small for gestational age
>90th percentile Large for gestational age
Between the 10th and 90th percentile Appropriate for gestational age


Intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR) refers to a fetal growth deficiency and an abnormal fetal growth trajectory. It is often classified as follows: 

Symmetric IUGR:

* Insult on fetal growth occurs early.

* As a result, head circumference, length, and weight are equally affected.

* It can be due to genetic causes, chromosomal disorders, or TORCH infections in the fetus.

Asymmetric IUGR

* Insult occurs in late gestation, producing a relative brain-sparing effect.

* The head circumference is relatively preserved compared to weight and length.

* It is caused by placental insufficiency, pregnancy-induced hypertension(PIH), poor maternal nutrition, or maternal medical diseases.

Severe maternal hypertension causes symmetric IUGR, while late-onset maternal vascular disease (PIH, preeclampsia) causes asymmetric IUGR.

questions.text: 19. In the following pressure-volume loop diagram of left ventricle, the mitral valve will close at the point:
questions.solution:
The closure of the mitral valve corresponds to point 2, which marks the beginning of the isovolumetric contraction phase.

 The pressure-volume curve represents the changes in volume and pressure in the left ventricle during a single cardiac cycle. The relationship between ventricular pressure (Y-axis) and volume (X-axis) throughout the cardiac cycle is represented by this loop.

* Point 1 - Mitral valve opens

* Point 2 - Mitral valve closes

* Point 3 - Aortic valve opens

* Point 4 - Aortic valve closes

Phase I: Period of filling:  

* In the given diagram, the period of filling lasts from point 1 to point 2.

* At point A, the volume of blood present in the left ventricle is the end-systolic volume which corresponds to about 50 ml. It is at this point that the mitral valve opens and the venous blood flows into the left ventricle from the left atrium.

* At point B, the end of the period of filling—the amount of blood present in the left ventricle is called the end-diastolic volume which corresponds to about 120 ml. It is at this point that the mitral valve closes.

Phase II: Period of isovolumic contraction:

* In the given diagram, the period of isovolumetric contraction lasts from point 2 to point 3.

* At point B, the mitral valve closes and the volume of the ventricle does not change as all the valves are closed. However, the pressure inside the ventricle continues to rise.

* At point C the ventricular pressure increases to become equal to the pressure in the aorta (80 mm Hg) and then the aortic valve opens.

Phase III: Period of ejection

* In the given diagram, the period of ejection lasts from point 3 to point 4.

* At point C, the aortic valve opens and the volume of the ventricle decreases as the blood flows out of the ventricle into the aorta.

* The systolic pressure continues to rise as the ventricle contracts.

* At point D the aortic valve closes.

Phase IV: Period of isovolumic relaxation

* In the given diagram, the period of relaxation lasts from point 4 to point 1.

* At point D, the aortic valve closes and the ventricular pressure falls back to the diastolic pressure level. 

* This decrease in intraventricular pressure occurs without any change in volume.

* At point A, the ventricle now has an end-systolic volume of 50 ml of blood similar to the beginning of the cycle.

questions.text: 20. Which of the following statement is true about the given dose response curve

choices.text: Drug B is the most potent
Drug B is the most efficacious
Drug C is more efficacious than drug D

questions.solution:
The more the curve on the left, more is its potency. Hence drug B is the most potent.

Potency:

* It is defined as the amount of drug needed to produce a given response.

* More the curve on the left side, more is its potency.

* Hence in the given DRC drug B is most potent and drug D is the least potent.

Efficacy:

* It is defined as the maximum effect produced by the drug and is determined by the peak of the curve.

* Hence in the given DRC, drug B has least efficacy and drug A, C & D are equally efficacious.
